title: Supervised vs. Unsupervised Learning
image_desc:
A modern abstract graphic depicting two contrasting data streams, one organized and structured (representing supervised learning), and the other chaotic and unstructured (representing unsupervised learning). Type: vector

### Video Suggestion:
A stock footage video showing a split screen: one side showing organized data flowing smoothly, the other showing a chaotic stream of data.
video_desc: A stock footage video showing a split screen: one side showing organized data flowing smoothly, the other showing a chaotic stream of data.
narration: en Welcome Today we'll explore the two most prevalent machine learning methods used in business supervised and unsupervised learning

title: Supervised Learning
content:
Uses structured data (labeled)
~20% of business data
Examples: Inventory control, recommendation engines, predictive maintenance
Sources: Human input, sensors, website logs, POS systems
image_desc:
A clean, organized database table with labeled columns and rows, representing structured data. Type: illustration

### Video Suggestion:
N/A
narration: en  Let's start with supervised learning This method utilizes structured data  data with labels like dates numbers or names This type of data typically found in relational databases makes up about twenty percent of all business data  Supervised learning is effective when you have a specific question or known output making it ideal for tasks like inventory control recommendation engines and predictive maintenance

title: Unsupervised Learning
content:
Uses unstructured data (unlabeled)
~80-90% of business data
Examples: Market segmentation, fraud detection, hardware fault diagnostics
Sources: Customer transactions, social media, documents, images, videos
image_desc:
A visual representation of a large, complex network of interconnected nodes, representing unstructured data. Type: illustration

### Video Suggestion:
N/A
narration: en Now let's look at unsupervised learning This approach tackles unstructured data  data without predefined labels This constitutes eighty to ninety percent of most organizations' data including customer transactions social media posts and various multimedia content  Unsupervised learning algorithms identify patterns and clusters within this data proving invaluable for market segmentation fraud detection and diagnosing hardware faults

title: Key Differences
content:
**Column 1: Supervised Learning**
Uses labeled data
Predicts outcomes
Requires pre-defined targets
**Column 2: Unsupervised Learning**
Uses unlabeled data
Discovers patterns
Identifies hidden structures
narration: en To summarize the key differences supervised learning uses labeled data to predict outcomes based on predefined targets  Unsupervised learning on the other hand works with unlabeled data to discover hidden patterns and structures within the information  The advantage of unsupervised learning as noted by Oliver Theobald is its ability to reveal previously unknown patterns such as distinct customer types

title: Conclusion
content: (Caption below image)  Understanding both supervised and unsupervised learning is crucial for leveraging the full potential of your data.
image_desc:
A graph showing the growth of both supervised and unsupervised learning applications over time, highlighting their increasing importance. Type: chart

### Video Suggestion:
N/A
narration: en In conclusion mastering both supervised and unsupervised learning methods is key to unlocking the full potential of your data  By understanding their strengths and applications businesses can gain valuable insights and make datadriven decisions Thank you
